page.title: 11Religion in Middleton
page.content: At one time, Middleton by Youlgrave was a strongly non-conformist village. Now only the Anglican church remains an active place of worship. Services are held twice a month with one evensong and one Holy Communion. Experimental liturgy is being introduced in the hope of reversing the decline in attendance. The presence of{Arbor Low}within the area adds a further religious dimension. Whether or not the stone circle was originally a mystical site, it is now used for certain rites on Midsummer morning. As at Stonehenge, dawn on the summer solstice is greeted by ceremony in the druidic tradition. The former Congregational Chapel is a house and the former Primitive Methodist Chapel was moved away to become a mine office. The mine had much trouble thereafter.
